conclusion: A particle starts from rest, and its acceleration over time follows a triangular wave pattern shown in the graph.
The particle's initial velocity is zero.
Acceleration is the derivative of velocity with respect to time.
Velocity is the derivative of position with respect to time.

The acceleration graph is a triangular wave: increasing linearly from 0 to \( a_0 \) until \( t = \frac{t_0}{2} \), then decreasing to 0 at \( t = t_0 \), decreasing to \( -a_0 \) at \( t = \frac{3t_0}{2} \), and back to 0 at \( t = 2t_0 \).
The acceleration \( a(t) \) can be expressed piecewise for different intervals of time.
Integrate \( a(t) \) to find the velocity function \( v(t) \) for each interval.
For \( \frac{t_0}{2} < t \leq t_0 \), integrate \( a(t) = -\frac{2a_0}{t_0} (t - t_0) + a_0 \) to find \( v(t) \).
For \( t_0 < t \leq \frac{3t_0}{2} \), integrate \( a(t) = -\frac{2a_0}{t_0} (t - t_0) \) to find \( v(t) \).
For \( \frac{3t_0}{2} < t \leq 2t_0 \), integrate \( a(t) = \frac{2a_0}{t_0} (t - 2t_0) + (-a_0) \) to find \( v(t) \).
The particle always moves in the positive direction.
At \( t=2t_0 \), the particle is farthest from the starting point.
